title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
summary: To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It is set in the Deep South and is a coming-of-age story featuring a young girl named Scout Finch and her father, lawyer Atticus Finch, who defends a black man accused of raping a white woman.
funny_fact: Harper Lee's father, Amasa Coleman Lee, was also a lawyer, and he served as a model for the character of Atticus Finch.

author: George Orwell
summary: 1984 is a dystopian novel by George Orwell published in 1949. It follows the life of Winston Smith, a low-ranking member of the Party, who struggles against the oppressive government of Oceania, ruled by the all-seeing Big Brother.
funny_fact: The term 'Big Brother' has become synonymous with oppressive surveillance and control.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
summary: The Catcher in the Rye is a novel by J.D. Salinger published in 1951. It follows the story of Holden Caulfield, a teenager expelled from prep school, who wanders through New York City encountering various people and reflecting on his experiences.
funny_fact: The title of the novel comes from a song by Robert Burns called 'Comin' Thro' the Rye.'

title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the first novel in the Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling. It follows the story of a young boy named Harry Potter who discovers he is a wizard and attends Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
funny_fact: J.K. Rowling wrote much of the book in cafes, as she was a single mother at the time and couldn't afford to heat her home.

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
summary: Pride and Prejudice is a romantic novel by Jane Austen published in 1813. It follows the story of Elizabeth Bennet as she deals with issues of manners, upbringing, morality, education, and marriage in the society of the landed gentry of early 19th-century England.
funny_fact: The novel was originally titled 'First Impressions' before Austen revised it and published it as 'Pride and Prejudice.'

title: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
summary: The Hobbit, or There and Back Again, is a fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien published in 1937. It follows the story of Bilbo Baggins, a hobbit who embarks on a quest to reclaim a treasure guarded by the dragon Smaug.
funny_fact: J.R.R. Tolkien wrote the book for his children and initially did not intend for it to be connected to his later work, 'The Lord of the Rings.'

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
summary: Moby-Dick is a novel by Herman Melville published in 1851. It tells the story of Ishmael, a sailor who joins the crew of the whaling ship Pequod, captained by the obsessed and vengeful Captain Ahab, who is in pursuit of the giant white whale Moby Dick.
funny_fact: The novel was a commercial failure during Melville's lifetime and was rediscovered and appreciated by critics in the 20th century.

title: The Lord of the Rings
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
summary: The Lord of the Rings is an epic high-fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien published in three volumes from 1954 to 1955. It follows the quest to destroy the One Ring, an artifact of great power created by the Dark Lord Sauron.
funny_fact: Tolkien began writing 'The Lord of the Rings' as a sequel to his earlier work, 'The Hobbit,' but it grew into a much larger and more complex story.

title: Frankenstein
author: Mary Shelley
summary: Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus is a novel by Mary Shelley published in 1818. It tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment.
funny_fact: Mary Shelley wrote Frankenstein when she was just 18 years old, and it was first published anonymously.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
summary: The Catcher in the Rye is a novel by J.D. Salinger published in 1951. It follows the story of Holden Caulfield, a teenager expelled from prep school, who wanders through New York City encountering various people and reflecting on his experiences.
funny_fact: The title of the novel comes from a song by Robert Burns called 'Comin' Thro' the Rye.'

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
summary: The Great Gatsby is a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald published in 1925. It is set in the Jazz Age on Long Island and follows the story of Jay Gatsby, a wealthy and enigmatic millionaire, and his love for the beautiful Daisy Buchanan.
funny_fact: F. Scott Fitzgerald's original title for the novel was 'Trimalchio in West Egg.'

title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
summary: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the first novel in the Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling. It follows the story of a young boy named Harry Potter who discovers he is a wizard and attends Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
funny_fact: J.K. Rowling wrote much of the book in cafes, as she was a single mother at the time and couldn't afford to heat her home.
